Instead: Force close and this error. What version of the product are you using? On what operating system? gdx 0.81, Windows 7, Eclipse Java EE IDE for Web Developers (Galileo) Please provide any additional information below. The project is hosted on my friends server. He's running it on XP and it works, but I get this error on my Win7 machine. Any reason?

data.title: gdx compilation is broken since r1253
data.body:
_From [igokoro](https://code.google.com/u/igokoro/) on December 22, 2010 09:55:24_

gdx compilation is broken since r1253 as BitmapFont trying to use private member "color" of the SpriteBatch .

Either give SpriteBatch .color member default (package) access modifier or return SpriteBatch .getColor().toFloatBits().

_Original issue: http://code.google.com/p/libgdx/issues/detail?id=84_

data.title: Rotate a bitmap font
data.body:
_From [tobias.w...@gmail.com](https://code.google.com/u/113866277779216050036/) on December 18, 2010 14:31:15_

If I have an object which holds a sprite and a corresponding text, I can rotate the sprite, but not the text.

Maybe I could do that with a seperate spriteBatch, but:
"A SpriteBatch is a pretty heavy object so you should only ever have one in your program."

So I think there are two options:
- BitmapFont.setRotation(float)
- or allow to make a Sprite from a BitmapFont (possible?)

_Original issue: http://code.google.com/p/libgdx/issues/detail?id=83_

data.title: onComplete method for Actions
Scaling of bitmap fonts
Texture dimensions must be a power of two
data.body:
_From [tobias.w...@gmail.com](https://code.google.com/u/113866277779216050036/) on December 14, 2010 15:11:31_

As far as I know OpenGL ES 2.0 doesn't need special texture dimensions with a power of two.

In JoglGraphicsBase.java:
if (!isPowerOfTwo(pixmap.getHeight())
        || !isPowerOfTwo(pixmap.getWidth()))
    throw new GdxRuntimeException(
        "Texture dimensions must be a power of two");

I changed it to:
if (gl!=gl20 && !isPowerOfTwo(pixmap.getHeight())
...

It seems to work now.

_Original issue: http://code.google.com/p/libgdx/issues/detail?id=76_

data.title: Backward compatibility fix
data.body:
_From [liquidro...@gmail.com](https://code.google.com/u/104052605842022108362/) on December 12, 2010 16:38:37_

When building libgdx in android 2.2 SDK to support SD card installation as mentioned in http://developer.android.com/guide/appendix/install-location.html , libgdx breaks(crash) on devices running android 1.6 or lower due to using undefined API to check for multitouch: PackageManager.hasSystemFeature()

This patch fixes that by using reflection method mentioned in http://developer.android.com/resources/articles/backward-compatibility.html to bind the API method dynamically for checking multitouch. When API method is not found, we can safely assume that there's no multitouch anyways.

It's sad that I did not notice this until it was too late. My game did not run for all 1.6 devices and got bad 1 star rating and > 50% uninstall rate due to this. :-( Really hope those guys would come back and give our game another try before rating us crappy 1 star again. Ah well, what's done is done. At least the bug is spotted and fixed. ;-)

Btw, I actually am reusing my lockless queue input patch hence I actually reverted my changes to build this patch. So it's untested but it should work.

_Original issue: http://code.google.com/p/libgdx/issues/detail?id=73_

data.title: Unable to decode MP3 with Mpg123Decoder
data.body:
_From [banthere...@gmail.com](https://code.google.com/u/101998865455852775403/) on December 12, 2010 00:04:00_

What steps will reproduce the problem? Mpg123Decoder mDecoder;
FileHandle mFile = Gdx.files.absolute("c:\valid\path\to\file.mp3");
if (mFile.exists()) mDecoder = new Mpg123Decoder(mFile.path());

======================================================= What is the expected output? What do you see instead? Should instantiate mDecoder, but am getting java.lang.UnsatisfiedLinkError: com.badlogic.gdx.audio.io.Mpg123Decoder.openFile(Ljava/lang/String;)

See full stack trace at bottom of ticket.

======================================================= What version of the product are you using? On what operating system? Lastest nightly build at 2:00pm PST on Dec, 11 2010. Window 7 Professional 64-bit.  Eclipse 3.5.  Tried both JOGL and LWJGL backends.

======================================================= Please provide any additional information below. I have the latest nightly build which, per the new blog entry, should work without "-Djava.library.path=libs/" in arguments.  Tried both.  It compiles fine without the VM argument, but looks like Mpg123 isn't linking.
# 

Stack trace

data.title: support for Matrix3 uniforms in ShaderProgram
data.body:
_From [can...@gmail.com](https://code.google.com/u/102115008550572502171/) on December 10, 2010 19:20:10_

When computing lighting, a "Normal" 3x3 matrix is needed to transform normals to world space. 

May be bypassed simulating a 3x3 matrix with a Matrix4 object with appropiate cells filled with zeroes, but i think it's a bit overhead because this matrix must be first computed as "worldMatrix.inv().tra()" (from a 4x4!).

Thanks in advance

_Original issue: http://code.google.com/p/libgdx/issues/detail?id=70_

data.title: Patch to remove lags when calling play/pause/stop of Music on desktop(jogl)
data.body:
_From [lf3th...@gmail.com](https://code.google.com/u/114271525039123168784/) on November 13, 2010 02:33:23_

When playing play/pause/stop, rendering thread waits for the music thread which causes lags.

This patch makes it instantaneous by making the music state atomic. This allows rendering thread to "set and forget". The music thread then handles it internally by matching the state.

_Original issue: http://code.google.com/p/libgdx/issues/detail?id=59_
